title: Help with complementary fonts for Hawaiian Aloha
content:
I am a novice that is designing an activity guide for my friends upcoming beach wedding. I like [Hawaiian Aloha](http://web.archive.org/web/20090627111528/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/btn/hawaiian-aloha-btn/) and I need a couple of complementary fonts for sub-headings and text.  
Any suggestions?
author: katy_bug

comments.content:
Since you’re leaning towards one typeface by type designer Stuart Sandler, why not go with two of his other creations?

Cocktail Shaker is a fun retro script that could work for subheads and Backtalk Sans might work for your text.

I love that combo . . . but Cocktail Shaker is too expensive for me since this is just a one time project. It is the perfect font to go with Hawaiian and Backtalk. Do you have an alternative to suggest?

[Glengary](http://web.archive.org/web/20090627111528/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/glengary-nf/) from Nick’s Fonts is a script at reasonable price (about eight bucks). Not quite as retro-cool as [Cocktail Shaker](http://web.archive.org/web/20090627111528/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/sideshow/cocktail-shaker/), though.

I just sucked it up and bought Cocktail Shaker since it is so perfect.

I just finished the booklet and it looks so good. Thank you!

Cheers - Kate
Cheers to you! Glad to hear that you went with your first choice. Have a great time on the beach. Maybe someone will shake up a cocktail for you there.
